title: Westminster attack: Images of the Mumbai attack flashed through my mind
text:
Watch | House of Commons on lockdown after shooting 00:24 
F rom the Telegraph's office on an upper floor of Parliament near Big Ben, it was a bang, followed by a scream, that alerted me to the horror of what was happening outside . 
It was about 2.40pm when I and my colleagues darted to our window overlooking Parliament Square to see what was going on. 
To our right, on the approach to Westminster Bridge, our attention was drawn to a commotion around a grey car that appeared to have crashed into the railings surrounding New Palace Yard. Air Ambulance outside the   Credit: PA 
O pposite the entrance to Westminster Underground station, people were running away from the car, clearly in a state of terror. Some were shouting and as they ran off in different directions, a group of around a dozen people dashed around the corner into Parliament Square. Watch | Parliament shooting eyewitness: 'man plunged big knife into policeman' 00:37 
O pposite the entrance to Westminster Underground station, people were running away from the car, clearly in a state of terror. Some were shouting and as they ran off in different directions, a group of around a dozen people dashed around the corner into Parliament Square. 
When they reached the iron double gates used as the vehicle entrance to New Palace Yard, - through which Theresa May had driven hours earlier when she arrived for Prime Minister’s Questions - they appeared to rush the gates, which are always manned by two uniformed policemen. Westminster terror attack shooting in pics 
F rom my vantage point directly opposite the gates, it was difficult to tell whether the gates had been forced open or the policemen had allowed people in to give them sanctuary. But it was quickly clear that Parliament was under attack. 
P olice officers in yellow high-vis jackets appeared to be making a grab for some of the intruders. People who had been about to leave through the pedestrian exit next to the vehicle gate turned around and ran for their lives towards Westminster Hall. Journalists in the press corridor began shouting to each other. “Oh my God, we’re being attacked!” shouted one. Watch | Eyewitnesses describe seeing bodies on Westminster Bridge 01:07 
O utside, a moment of confusion: those who had run in through the gates mixed with those who had already been inside the railings as they all ran in the same direction. Policemen darted in different directions, clearly struggling to make sense of what was going on. 
Then, the confirmation that this was an attack on Parliament: a man who appeared to be carrying a knife, who got around 25 yards inside the gates, was rushing towards a policeman who pulled a pistol and fired three shots into his chest from around six feet away. Knocked off his feet by the impact of the bullets, he fell backwards onto the cobbles. Westminster Bridge scene 
I nside the building, journalists started to fear for their own lives, terrified that this might be a marauding attack and that accomplices might be trying to enter the building. 
“What do we do? Do we run?” my colleagues asked. I told them to stay put, and within a minute a female uniformed police officer appeared at the door of our office telling us to stay where we were, to shut the door and stay put. 
We were drawn back to the window, despite knowing that the advice is to stay away from windows in the event of a terrorist attack. Watch | Parliament shooting: Map locator of the areas involved 00:31 
O utside, two people were lying on the cobbles in New Palace Yard - the man shot by the policeman, and another person who I later found out was a policeman who had been attacked. I hadn’t seen the policeman being injured but his colleagues and a man in a suit were frantically giving him CPR. 
A round 15 yards from him, a man in a high-vis jacket was pumping the chest of the man who had been shot. 
We still had no idea whether we were safe. Watching what was happening at least provided a distraction from our own fears. Images of the Mumbai attack flashed through my mind as I wondered whether a terrorist had managed to get into the building. Westminster attack locator map 
A cross the patch of grass in the centre of New Palace Yard, I looked at the ramp to the underground car park and remembered black and white images of the last terrorist attack on the Parliamentary estate, when the Conservative MP Airey Neave was killed by an IRA car bomb on that spot in 1979. 
My heart racing, I made brief phone calls to the Telegraph newsdesk to alert them to what was going on, to my partner to reassure her I was safe, and began tweeting my first reports of what I had seen. Only then did I see others tweeting about the car ploughing into pedestrians on Westminster Bridge. 
An air ambulance landed in the middle of Parliament Square. Moments later two ambulances arrived and paramedics took over from the police officers attending to the two people on the ground. Watch | Armed police at Westminster after shots fired 00:48 
T he man in the suit who had been helping administer first aid to the injured police officer peeled away and we could see that it was Tobias Ellwood, the Foreign Office minister and former soldier whose brother died in the Bali terrorist attack. 
H e had blood on his hands. A woman hugged him. In our office, we finally drew breath, beginning to believe that the worst was over.
